sections.title: Mapping the Wetlands of Canterbury
sections.content:
Wetlands in Canterbury have been mapped and described using the systems, techniques and classifications of Johnson & Gerbeaux (2004), Clackson et al. (2003) and Atkinson (1985). Primary classification was based on vegetation structure (e.g shrubland, reedland herbfield). Additional describers were wetland landform and hydrology.

 

Atkinson, I.A.E. 1985. Derivation of vegetation mapping units for an ecological survey of Tongariro National Park, North Island, New Zealand. New Zealand Journal of Botany 23: 361-378.

 

Clarkson, B.R.; Sorrell, B.K.; Reeves, P.N.; Champion, P.D.; Partridge, T.R.; Clarkson, B.D. 2003. Handbook for monitoring wetland condition. Coordinated monitoring of New Zealand wetlands. A Ministry for the Environment SMF funded project. Ministry for the Environment, Wellington. 74pp.

 

Johnson, P.; Gerbeaux, P. 2004. Wetland Types in New Zealand. Department of Conservation, Wellington. 184pp.

sections.title: Ashburton Coastline
sections.content:
Ashburton River Hapua  

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Lacustrine, shallow water and bare ground

Significance: High

Threat: Moderate

Condition Index: 19.5

 

The Ashburton River mouth is a ‘small river hapua’ that is frequently closed to the sea, as it was at time of survey. At that time the wetland comprised freshwater riverine and lacustrine hydrosystems where the braided river discharged into a freshwater lagoon impounded behind the gravel beach barrier. Because of its highly dynamic nature, the Ashburton River hapua does not support wetland vegetation.

 

Link to field report 

 

 

Coldstream Coast

 

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Palustrine marsh

Significance: Moderate

Threat: High

Condition Index: 14.0

 

Mapped area consists of multiple coastal dongas, located along a section of eroding coastal cliffs. At time of survey the vegetated wetland area was estimated as comprising approximately 95% freshwater wetland habitats, and 5% non-tidal estuarine saltmarsh.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Hinds River Mouth Hapua

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Lacustrine coastal lagoon with intermittent opening to sea. Mostly unvegetated gravels and open water. Small vegetated areas are marsh

Significance: Moderate

Threat: High

Condition Index: 17.0

 

Hapua at mouth of Hinds River. Fluctuating water levels, little wetland vegetation.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Longbeach Coast

 

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Palustrine swamp and marsh

Significance: Moderate

Threat: Moderate

Condition Index: 13.6

 

Wetlands occupy a series of coastal dongas. Approximately 80% of the surveyed wetland areas are freshwater palustrine and 20% freshwater riverine; <1% was estuarine saltmarsh.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Rangitata River Hapua

 

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Lacustrine, shallow water and bare ground

Significance: High

Threat: Moderate

Condition Index: 17.5

 

At time of survey, the Rangitata hapua combined an area of lacustrine freshwater ‘lagoon’ hydrosystem at its northern end with riverine hydrosystem at its southern end. Relative extent of these two main hydrosystems shifts with location of the hapua outlet along the beach barrier. Both lacustrine and riverine sections of the hapua are subject to tidal influence, but due to the volume of inflows, remain largely freshwater habitats. Due to its highly dynamic nature, the Rangitata River hapua supports little wetland vegetation, with limited areas of freshwater marsh along the margins of the hapua, and an adjoining area of estuarine saltmarsh habitat.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Wakanui Stream

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Palustrine swamp and marsh

Significance: Moderate

Threat: High

Condition Index: 13.4

 

No Description Provided.

 

Link to field report

sections.title: Banks Peninsula
sections.content:
Akaroa Harbour

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Estuarine tidal saltmarsh

Significance: Moderate

Threat: Moderate

Condition Index: 17.7

 

The wetland area is located at the head of Akaroa Harbour, between French Farm and Takamatua. Approximately 90% of area is tidal, unvegetated mudflats and 10% is saltmarsh herbfield, reedland, rushland and grassland. <1% is palustrine swamp.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Jubilee Stream (1) - Wainui

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Palustrine marsh

Significance: High

Threat: Moderate

Condition Index: 19.1

 

Approximately 75% of the surveyed area is palustrine marsh; 20% riverine marsh; and the remaining 5% mixed treeland and grassland.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Jubilee Stream (2) - Wainui

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Palustrine marsh

Significance: Moderate

Threat: Moderate

Condition Index: 18.3

 

Approximately 80% of the surveyed area is palustrine marsh; and 20% riverine marsh.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Jubilee Stream (3) - Wainui

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Palustrine marsh

Significance: Moderate

Threat: High

Condition Index: 17.3

 

Approximately 80% of the surveyed area is palustrine marsh and 20% riverine marsh.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Lake Forsyth_Wairewa

 

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Palustrine marsh

Significance: High

Threat: Moderate

Condition Index: 13.6

 

No Description Provided.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Le Bons Bay

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Estuarine tidal saltmarsh

Significance: High

Threat: Moderate

Condition Index: 18.7

 

Tidal estuary formed by Le Bons Bay Stream. Approximately 80% of surveyed area is unvegetated tidal sand and mud flats; with saltmarsh vegetation on margins of estuary and tidal river.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Lyttelton Harbour

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Estuarine tidal saltmarsh

Significance: High

Threat: Moderate

Condition Index: 16.0

 

Saltmarsh and unvegetated mudflats in bays at the head of Lyttelton harbour. 80% of area is unvegetated tidal mudflats.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Okains Bay

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Estuarine tidal saltmarsh

Significance: High

Threat: Moderate

Condition Index: 19.0

 

Tidal estuary formed by Okains Bay Stream. Approximately 75% of surveyed area is unvegetated tidal sand and mud flats; with saltmarsh vegetation on margins of estuary and tidal river.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Raupo Bay

 

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Estuarine, non-tidal, saltmarsh

Significance: High

Threat: Moderate

Condition Index: 19.8

 

Wetland formed by sand dunes impounding the small stream draining the Raupō Bay catchment. Wetland habitats areas are estuarine non-tidal saltmarsh with fringing areas of supra-tidal saltmarsh.

 

Link to field report

sections.title: Christchurch City Coastline
sections.content:
Avon- Heathcote Estuary Ihutai

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Estuarine tidal saltmarsh

Significance: High

Threat: High

Condition Index: 15.1

 

Majority (>80%) of wetland area is un-vegetated tidal mud and sand flats, with saltmarsh wetland habitats on the estuary margins and along tidal reaches of the inflowing rivers. There are also some adjoining freshwater wetland habitats but these cover less than 1% of the vegetated wetland area.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Brooklands Lagoon

 

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Estuarine tidal saltmarsh

Significance: High

Threat: Moderate

Condition Index: 15.5

 

Estuary consisting of river delta mud and sand flats and saltmarsh behind a sand dune barrier.Majority (>75%) of wetland area is un-vegetated. Of the vegetated wetland area, 94% is estuarine saltmarsh habitat, with small areas of adjoining riverine and palustrine freshwater wetland habitats.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Dickies Reserve

 

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Palustrine swamp and marsh

Significance: High

Threat: High

Condition Index: 14.5

 

Permanent spring-fed swamp with outflowing drains and surrounding seasonal marsh habitats. Site has a mixed willow canopy but native wetland vegetation species dominate the understory.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Styx River Mouth - Te Rauakaaka

 

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Estuarine tidal saltmarsh

Significance: High

Threat: Moderate

Condition Index: 15.2

 

Of the c. 60 ha wetland area, about two-thirds % is tidal saltmarsh. Other main wetland habitats are palustrine swamp, riverine marsh and ‘relict’ saltmarsh. Wetland extent and hydrology has been affected by drains and river engineering works.

 

Link to field report

sections.title: Hurunui Coastline
sections.content:
Amberley Beach Lagoon

 

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Palustrine swamp

Significance: Moderate

Threat: Moderate

Condition Index: 17.0

 

Mostly swamp and open water with small areas of marsh on margins.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Ashworths Ponds

 

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Estuarine, non-tidal saltmarsh dune slack

Significance: High

Threat: Moderate

Condition Index: 18.5

 

Highly variable water levels and salinity, ponds joined at times. The wetlands are brackish - fed by groundwater inflows with periodic sea water incursion. At the time of survey approximately 82% of the area was estuarine herbfield, reedland, rushland and grassland, 17% open water and 1% terrestrial grassland.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Conway River Mouth Lagoon

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Estuarine coastal lagoon with intermittent opening to sea. Vegetated area is mostly saltmarsh with some freshwater wetland; unvegetated area silt, gravel or shallow water

Significance: High

Threat: Moderate

Condition Index: 17.3

 

Coastal lagoon and hapua at mouth of Conway River. Contains estuarine (brackish) saltmarsh, freshwater lacustrine and palustrine wetland habitats.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Gore Bay - Buxton Creek

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Estuarine coastal lagoon with intermittent opening to sea. Vegetated area is saltmarsh, unvegetated area sand or shallow water

Significance: Moderate

Threat: Moderate

Condition Index: 21.2

 

Approximately 55% of the defined wetland area is palustrine swamp; 20% palustrine marsh and the remaining 25% native terrestrial shrubland (15%) and exotic terrestrial grassland (10%).

 

Link to field report

 

 

Gore Bay - Jed River Mouth

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Estuarine coastal lagoon with intermittent opening to sea. Vegetated area is mostly saltmarsh with terrestrial vegetation on stable islands, unvegetated area either riverbed or shallow water

Significance: Moderate

Threat: Moderate

Condition Index: 15.5

 

Approximately 28% of the mapped wetland area is estuarine saltmarsh, this comprises 12% herbfield, 6% reedland and 10% shrubland; the remaining 72% is exotic terrestrial habitat. This is comprised of herbfield (22%), grassland (20%), shrubland (14%) and treeland (16%).

 

Link to field report

 

 

Hurunui River Hapua

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Riverine, tidal, shallow water, unvegetated gravels and sand

Significance: High

Threat: Moderate

Condition Index: 21.4

 

At time of survey, the Hurunui hapua consisted of a lacustrine freshwater ‘lagoon’ hydrosystem at its northern end, combined with a more dynamic riverine hydrosystem to the south. Relative extent of these two main hydrosystems shifts with location of the hapua outlet along the beach barrier. Both lacustrine and riverine sections of the hapua are subject to tidal influence, but due to the volume of inflows, remain freshwater habitats for most of the time. Because of its highly dynamic nature, the Hurunui River hapua supports very little wetland vegetation.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Kowai River Mouth

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Estuarine non-tidal saltmarsh

Significance: Moderate

Threat: High

Condition Index: 15.7

 

Approximately 30% of the wetland area is a coastal lagoon with saltmarsh herbfield and open water/gravel; 70% is a swale with saltmarsh shrubland, reedland and rushland.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Leithfield Lagoon

 

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Lacustrine, swamp

Significance: Moderate

Threat: Moderate

Condition Index: 14.2

 

Freshwater coastal lagoon near Leithfield Beach, north Pegasus Bay. Approximately 65% of the wetland area is open-water, 20% forest and 20% reedland.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Mimimoto Lagoon

 

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Palustrine, marsh

Significance: Moderate

Threat: Moderate

Condition Index: 14.7

 

Approximately 45% of the wetland area is palustrine rushland/shrubland, 25% terrestrial shrubland/grassland, 20% open-water, 8% lacustrine reedland and <1% estuarine reedland/grassland

 

Link to field report

 

 

Moelean Swamp

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Palustrine swamp

Significance: High

Threat: Moderate

Condition Index: 16.8

 

No Description Provided.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Motunau River Mouth

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Estuarine tidal saltmarsh. Mostly unvegetated, sand and mudflats.

Significance: Moderate

Threat: Moderate

Condition Index: 17.9

 

No Description Provided.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Waiau River Hapua

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Riverine, tidal, shallow water, unvegetated gravels and sand

Significance: High

Threat: Moderate

Condition Index: 22.0

 

At time of survey, the Waiau hapua consisted of a lacustrine freshwater ‘lagoon’ hydrosystem at its northern end, combined with a more dynamic riverine hydrosystem to the south. Relative extent of these two main hydrosystems shifts with location of the hapua outlet along the beach barrier. Both lacustrine and riverine sections of the hapua are subject to tidal influence, but due to the volume of inflows, remain largely freshwater habitats. Because of its highly dynamic nature, the Waiau River hapua does not support wetland vegetation.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Waipara River Mouth

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Estuarine saltmarsh lagoon, opening to sea sporadic, water level highly variable.

Significance: High

Threat: Moderate

Condition Index: 16.6

 

Wetland area covers the Waipara River hapua as well as a series of swales and floodplain at the base of the marine terrace north of the river. The extent and salinity of the hapua water is highly variable, both temporally and spatially, due to periodic opening and closing of the beach barrier as well as fluctuations in freshwater inflows.

 

Link to field report

sections.title: Hurunui River  (Upper Catchment)
sections.content:
Maori Gully

 

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Palustrine swamp and marsh

Significance: Moderate

Threat: Moderate

Condition Index: 18.0

 

Wetland is located at the base of a scarp on an elevated terrace, above Māori Gully on the Hurunui River.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Sisters Stream

 

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Palustrine marsh, swamp, shallow water and seepage

Significance: Moderate

Threat: Moderate

Condition Index: 17.2

 

Tributary of the Hurunui River, fed by Lake Taylor and Lake Sheppard outlets, as well as small streams from surrounding hills.

 

Link to field report

sections.title: Kaikoura Coastline
sections.content:
Tirohanga Lagoon

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Riverine marsh

Significance: Moderate

Threat: Low

Condition Index: 19.3

 

No Description Provided.

 

Link to field report

sections.title: South Canterbury Coastline
sections.content:
Highfield

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Palustrine swamp

Significance: High

Threat: Moderate

Condition Index: 16.8

 

Wetland associated with spring-fed creek on South Canterbury downlands.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Makikihi Coast

 

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Estuarine non-tidal saltmarsh.

Significance: Moderate

Threat: Moderate

Condition Index: 14.1

 

A swale, constructed stopbank and drain channel sequence. At the time of survey, approximately 50% of the survey area was classified as estuarine saltmarsh and 50% as palustrine swamp and marsh.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Makikihi River Mouth

 

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Riverine shallow water and bare gravel

Significance: Low

Threat: Moderate

Condition Index: 16.5

 

The wetland consists mainly of unvegetated gravel, mud and sand. Small areas of exotic vegetation on undisturbed river gravels.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Otaio Flats

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Palustrine shallow water and marsh

Significance: Moderate

Threat: High

Condition Index: 11.5

 

Includes Kohika Lagoon. Site hydrology and wetland form highly modified by network of drains and stopbanks.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Otaio River Mouth

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Riverine shallow water

Significance: Moderate

Threat: Moderate

Condition Index: 18.3

 

Area consists of, mainly, unvegetated gravel, mud and sand; with small areas of exotic vegetation on undisturbed river gravels.

 

Link to field report

 

 

St Andrews Coast

 

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Riverine marsh

Significance: Moderate

Threat: Moderate

Condition Index: 14.1

 

Exotic vegetation dominates the main riverine wetland area. Occasional seawater inundation retains some salt tolerant native vegetation in the smaller dune slack and donga. At time of survey the vegetated wetland area was estimated as comprising approximately 60% freshwater wetland habitats, and 40% non-tidal estuarine saltmarsh.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Waihao Dead Arm

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Lacustrine marsh

Significance: High

Threat: Moderate

Condition Index: 12.0

 

Hydrology and salinity of Waihao Box lagoon and Dead Arm is variable, depending largely on whether the box is open or shut. At time of survey the box was closed, the lagoon was fresh water, and margin vegetation was mostly freshwater wetland communities. Areas of saltmarsh vegetation were present at intervals along the seaward side of the lagoon.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Wainono Lagoon

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Brackish coastal lagoon. Most margins non-tidal saltmarsh wetland habitat; palustrine freshwater wetland at NW end.

Significance: High

Threat: High

Condition Index: 13.2

 

Approximately 75% of lakeshore wetland is estuarine (brackish coastal lagoon); 14% is freshwater wetland, mostly palustrine swamp, with a small area of freshwater lacustrine marsh habitats in vicinity of inflows.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Waitaki River Hapua

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Lacustrine, hapua

Significance: High

Threat: Moderate

Condition Index: 18.2

 

No Description Provided.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Willowbridge Coast

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Estuarine non-tidal & supra-tidal, saltmarsh

Significance: Moderate

Threat: High

Condition Index: 13.0

 

Sequence of small wetlands along the coastline between Waihao Box and Waitaki River mouth. Includes two coastal lagoons, dune slacks and a swale. Overall the area comprises approximately 75% saltmarsh/brackish wetland and 25% freshwater wetland habitats

 

Link to field report

sections.title: Orari-Opihi-Pareora Coastline
sections.content:
Normanby Lagoon

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Estuarine non-tidal saltmarsh.

Significance: Moderate

Threat: High

Condition Index: 16.2

 

Small, slightly brackish shallow coastal lagoon at mouth of unnamed creek. Relative extent of lagoon water and vegetated herbfield margins varies.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Opihi River Mouth Lagoon

 

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Lacustrine shallow water and marsh

Significance: High

Threat: Moderate

Condition Index: 14.9

 

This wetland includes the rivermouth behind the shingle bar and associated coastal lagoons. The Opihi Rivermouth lagoon, and associated Orakipaoa Creek lagoon, has a complex and dynamic hydrology – sometimes a largely freshwater body; at others open to tidal seawater inflows and/or seawater overtopping the beach barrier. It supports a high diversity of wetland habitats including deep and shallow water, beach gravel, meandering channels and mud flats, with extensive areas of native rush, sedge and reedland vegetation on margins. At time of survey the vegetated wetland area was estimated as comprising approximately 60% freshwater wetland habitats, and 40% non-tidal estuarine saltmarsh.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Orari River Mouth Lagoons

 

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Palustrine marsh

Significance: High

Threat: Moderate

Condition Index: 12.3

 

Area extensively modified with stopbanks, drains, weirs and culverts. Vegetation dominated by exotics with patches of native herbfield, rushland, reedland, open water and unvegetated gravel. Approximately 41% of the mapped area is palustrine, 36% is lacustrine, 15% estuarine and 8% terrestrial.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Pareora Coast

 

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Estuarine supra-tidal saltmarsh

Significance: Low

Threat: High

Condition Index: 14.2

 

At the time of survey approximately 40% of the wetland area was estuarine saltmarsh and 60% palustrine marsh.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Pareora River Mouth

 

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Palustrine, marsh and swamp

Significance: High

Threat: Moderate

Condition Index: 15.2

 

At the time of survey approximately 50% of the wetland area was freshwater palustrine habitat, and 50% was estuarine and riverine shallow water and river gravel/sand/mud.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Pig Hunting Creek

 

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Estuarine non-tidal saltmarsh

Significance: Moderate

Threat: Moderate

Condition Index: 16.2

 

Small brackish coastal lagoon with saltmarsh vegetation on margins. Majority of area (> 90%) estuarine; palustrine and riverine freshwater wetland habitats at upstream end.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Prattley Road Lagoon

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Palustrine shallow water and marsh

Significance: Moderate

Threat: Moderate

Condition Index: 14.5

 

Isolated section of the Opihi River lagoon; connection lost due to river engineering works. At the time of survey >95% of the survey area was freshwater palustrine wetland and <5% was estuarine saltmarsh.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Saltwater Creek - Otipua Wetland

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Estuarine, non-tidal, saltmarsh

Significance: Moderate

Threat: High

Condition Index: 14.1

 

Site includes the lower reaches of Saltwater Creek, the adjoining Otipua wetland restoration area, and brackish coastal lagoon impounded behind beach barrier. Approximately 60% of the total area is freshwater wetland (palustrine and riverine) habitats; 40% saltmarsh / brackish wetland habitat. Of the vegetated area, about 80% is freshwater wetland and 20% saltmarsh plant communities.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Seaforth Coast

 

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Estuarine non-tidal & supra-tidal, saltmarsh

Significance: High

Threat: Moderate

Condition Index: 14.7

 

Sequence of coastal wetland habitats including swale, dune slacks and a spring-fed coastal lagoon. Wetland habitats are mostly estuarine (>90%), with small areas of lacustrine and riverine habitat.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Spider Lagoon

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Palustrine swamp and shallow water

Significance: High

Threat: Moderate

Condition Index: 15.3

 

Wetland area is 40% estuarine saltmarsh and 60% palustrine shallow water/swamp; of this 65% is open water.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Tuhawaiki Point

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Estuarine, supra-tidal, saltmarsh

Significance: Moderate

Threat: Moderate

Condition Index: 17.4

 

Estuarine wetlands associated with seasonal streams. Main area is a large dune slack with native reedland and herbfield vegetation; secondary area is a flood channel containing mainly exotic grassland.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Washdyke Lagoon

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Estuarine, non-tidal, saltmarsh

Significance: High

Threat: High

Condition Index: 14.1

 

Shallow, brackish coastal lagoon behind gravel beach barrier. The wider wetland area is subdivided by stopbanks, with saltmarsh seaward of stopbanks and freshwater palustrine marsh landward. Of vegetated wetland area, approximately 75% is saltmarsh, and 25% freshwater wetland plant communities.

 

Link to field report

sections.title: Selwyn-Waihora Coastline
sections.content:
Coopers Lagoon_Muriwai

 

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Freshwater coastal lagoon, not naturally open to the sea. Main water source a combination of spring-fed stream and groundwater inflows. Lacustrine marsh habitat on wetland margins.

Significance: High

Threat: High

Condition Index: 14.8

 

Shallow coastal lagoon and associated margin wetlands. Although located immediately behind beach barrier, the lagoon is mostly a freshwater wetland habitat because of the volume of fresh surface and groundwater inflows. Approximately 10% of mapped vegetated wetlands are estuarine saltmarsh vegetation types – mostly along the edge of the lagoon’s NE corner.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Jollies Brook - Cryers Creek

 

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Estuarine saltmarsh

Significance: High

Threat: High

Condition Index: 14.6

 

Freshwater stream/wetland complex that occupies a swale located on the coast between Coopers Lagoon and the Rakaia River hapua.

 

Link to field report

 

 

McKenzie Farm, Rakaia

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Palustrine swamp and marsh

Significance: High

Threat: High

Condition Index: 9.2

 

McKenzie Farm was assessed as part of Regional Council investigation into unconsented drainage, vegetation clearance and works in waterways. The wetland is associated with a spring-fed stream on the northern floodplain of the Rakaia River. At time of survey vegetation from private adjoining un-allocated crown land had been cleared, and the area fenced and sown in pasture. Some wetland habitats remained but were threatened by further farm development.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Rakaia River Hapua

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Riverine, tidal, shallow water, unvegetated gravels and sand

Significance: High

Threat: Moderate

Condition Index: 18.1

 

At time of survey, the Rakaia hapua consisted of a relatively stable lacustrine freshwater ‘lagoon’ hydrosystem at its northern end, combined with a more dynamic riverine hydrosystem to the south. Relative extent of these two main hydrosystems shifts with location of the hapua outlet along the beach barrier. Both lacustrine and riverine sections of the hapua are subject to tidal influence, but due to the volume of inflows, remain largely freshwater habitats. Due to their highly dynamic nature, large river hapua generally support little or no wetland vegetation. At the Rakaia, there are limited areas of freshwater marsh along the inland margin at the relatively stable the northern end of the hapua. There are also some adjoining areas of palustrine swamp habitat.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Te Waihora Lake Ellesmere

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Estuarine non-tidal saltmarsh

Significance: High

Threat: High

Condition Index: 13.2

 

Approximately 86% of lakeshore wetland is estuarine (brackish coastal lagoon); 14% is freshwater wetland, mostly palustrine swamp, marsh and fen, with small areas of freshwater lacustrine marsh habitats in vicinity of inflows.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Tent Burn

 

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Paustrine swamp

Significance: High

Threat: Moderate

Condition Index: 16.2

 

At time of survey the vegetated wetland area was estimated as comprising approximately 60% freshwater swamp/shallow water and 40% freshwater marsh habitats.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Yarrs Lagoon

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Palustrine swamp and marsh

Significance: High

Threat: High

Condition Index: 13.2

 

Remnant swamp and marsh wetland habitat centred on District Council reserve at former open water area (‘Yarrs Lagoon’) along mid-reaches of spring-fed LII River.

 

Link to field report

sections.title: Rakaia River (Upper Catchment)
sections.content:
Coleridge Downs

 

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Palustrine swamp and marsh

Significance: Moderate

Threat: Moderate

Condition Index: 18.5

 

Approximately 55% of the surveyed area is palustrine swamp; 20% palustrine marsh and the remaining 25% native terrestrial shrubland (15%) and exotic terrestrial grassland (10%).

 

Link to field report

 

 

Coleridge Downs 2

 

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Palustrine fen & swamp

Significance: High

Threat: Moderate

Condition Index: 18.2

 

Large, varied valley floor swamp and fen habitat. Drainage and pasture development has affected wetland hydrology and reduced wetland area by around 40%. Pines, willows and other woody weeds are invading the remaining wetland. Up-slope area is dominated by native terrestrial shrubland.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Constance Geneva

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Palustrine ephemeral wetland

Significance: Moderate

Threat: Moderate

Condition Index: 19.2

 

Two small ephemeral tarns a stream channel and a fen; all located in a montane valley floor.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Glenthorne Lodge

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Palustrine swamp & shallow water

Significance: Moderate

Threat: Moderate

Condition Index: 21.5

 

Small wetland remnant located in a channel and depression surrounded by semi-developed farmland. Vegetation is dominated by harakeke, red tussock and bog rush.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Hennah-Ryton Stream Junction

 

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Palustrine swamp, fen amd marsh

Significance: Moderate

Threat: Low

Condition Index: 21.3

 

Wetlands located on either side of Hennah Stream, in an undeveloped valley floor, just above confluence with Ryton Stream.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Homestead Road pond and wetlands

 

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Palustrine swamp & shallow water

Significance: Moderate

Threat: Low

Condition Index: 21.2

 

Valley floor wetlands and pond associated with a first order stream. Willows dominate the canopy in the roadside wetlands, but the pond and inflowing stream have a large area of riparian raupō and flax.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Idaburn wetland complex

 

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Palustrine fen

Significance: High

Threat: Moderate

Condition Index: 21.9

 

Idaburn wetland complex is the largest wetland area in the Coleridge ecological district. The main wetlands are fed from streams running out of Lake Catherine and Lake Ida; and surface and groundwater inflows sourced from Ryton Stream and the surrounding hills. Some wetland areas are threatened by willow and wilding conifer spread.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Lake Coleridge Lagoons

 

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: None

Significance: Not Specified

Threat: Not Specified

Condition Index: None

 

Permanent harakeke swamp and associated seasonal ponds located on the edge of Ryton Bay, Lake Coleridge.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Lake Evelyn and Mt Hennah swamp

 

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Lacustrine swamp & shallow water

Significance: High

Threat: Low

Condition Index: 21.8

 

Montane lake with unmodified hydrology and intact, native lakeshore and wetland vegetation; surrounding catchment mostly native forest, shrub and tussock vegetation with some extensive stock grazing.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Lake Georgina wetland margins

 

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Lacustrine shallow water & marsh

Significance: High

Threat: Low

Condition Index: 21.4

 

Small montane lake surrounded by low producing grassland and mixed shrubland. Popular fishing & camping site. Important habitat for Southern crested grebe.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Lake Henrietta

 

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Palustrine swamp & shallow water

Significance: High

Threat: Low

Condition Index: 21.3

 

Montane lake and wetland with largely unmodified hydrology and intact, native wetland and lakeshore vegetation; surrounding catchment mostly native shrub and tussock vegetation.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Lake Lyndon ephemeral wetland

 

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Lacustrine marsh

Significance: High

Threat: Low

Condition Index: 17.1

 

Ephemeral lacustrine wetland bordering a montane lake (Lake Lyndon); dry at time of survey but often floods in winter-spring. Vegetation a mix of native and exotic seral species, that either tolerate inundation, or quickly establish after water recedes.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Lake Selfe wetland margins

 

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Palustrine fen

Significance: Moderate

Threat: Low

Condition Index: 21.3

 

Small areas of wetland vegetation on margins of montane lake. Most of the shoreline is unvegetated. Surrounding catchment is mostly native tussockland and shrubland; extensively grazed.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Little River wetland - Cleardale Station

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Palustrine marsh

Significance: Moderate

Threat: Moderate

Condition Index: 18.7

 

Wetland at the base of a terrace adjoining the Rakaia River has native vegetation cover of raupo, flax, bog rush and Carex coriacea sedgeland. It has formed against the distal edge of a tributary river fan (Little River). The water supply is a creek and springs sourced from Little River catchment. Wetland hydrology may have been modified by the construction of a hydro-electric power station that diverts from Little River and then re-supplies the water further down the channel.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Lyndon-Harper Road wetlands

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Palustrine fen & swamp

Significance: High

Threat: Moderate

Condition Index: 16.7

 

Diverse wetland site with native shrubland, tussockland and remnant beech patches on the uphill slope; exotic shrubland and forest below and highly developed pasture in the centre.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Lyndon Road fen

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Palustrine fen

Significance: Moderate

Threat: Moderate

Condition Index: 22.1

 

Red tussock fen on the edge of Coleridge Torlesse and Craigieburn ecological districts. Ecological district boundary is the one adopted by Harding 2009 and Shanks et al. (1990).

 

Link to field report

 

 

Montrose

 

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Palustrine marsh, shallow water & swamp

Significance: High

Threat: Moderate

Condition Index: 17.2

 

Montrose wetland lies at the base of a terrace adjoining the Rakaia River. Several springs arising from the terrace scarp feed the wetland. Hydrology has been considerably modified by the construction of bunds, culverts and weirs. Palustrine habitats dominate the wetland (70%), with 25% lacustrine and 5% riverine also present.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Moss Burn

 

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Palustrine swamp & fen

Significance: High

Threat: Moderate

Condition Index: 19.5

 

Montane moraine wetland with intact, native wetland and riparian vegetation; surrounding catchment was mostly native shrub and tussock vegetation, but recent vegetation clearance, pasture development and fencing of the wetland has lowered the naturalness of the site.

 

Link to field report

sections.title: Waimakariri Coastline
sections.content:
Ashley River - Saltwater Creek Lagoon

 

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Estuarine, tidal, saltmarsh

Significance: High

Threat: Moderate

Condition Index: 16.3

 

Estuary consisting of river delta mud and sand flats and saltmarsh behind a sand dune barrier. Majority (>75%) of wetland area is unvegetated. Of the vegetated wetland area, 94% is estuarine saltmarsh habitat, with small areas of adjoining riverine and palustrine freshwater wetland habitats.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Jockey Baker Creek

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Palustrine swamp

Significance: Moderate

Threat: Moderate

Condition Index: 15.0

 

Lower reaches of creek and confluence with Waimakariri River. Majority (70%) of c. 15 ha wetland area is palustrine swamp; 20% riverine marsh; 10% estuarine tidal saltmarsh habitat.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Kairaki Creek

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Estuarine tidal saltmarsh

Significance: Moderate

Threat: Moderate

Condition Index: 11.5

 

Tidal, estuarine; tributary of the Waimakariri River. 36% estuarine grassland, shrubland, rushland and reedland; 30% open water; 22% riverine treeland and 12% palustrine forest.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Pines Beach Wetland

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Palustrine marsh

Significance: Moderate

Threat: Moderate

Condition Index: 18.0

 

Dune slack wetland in late stages of transition from estuarine to palustrine hydrology. Relictual saltmarsh species scattered within mainly freshwater vegetation. Limited catchment area, water levels fluctuate depending on groundwater and rainfall inputs.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Tutaepatu Lagoon-Waikuku

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Palustrine swamp

Significance: High

Threat: High

Condition Index: 14.2

 

Approximately 88% of the wetland area is palustrine grassland, rushland and forest, 5% terrestrial herbfield/grassland, 5% lacustrine open water and 2% riverine treeland and open water.

 

Link to field report

sections.title: Waimakariri River (Lower Catchment)
sections.content:
Germans Road – Ashley Gorge

 

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Palustrine marsh

Significance: Moderate

Threat: High

Condition Index: 14.7

 

Remnant Juncus edgariae rushland in an area of developed pasture. Drainage, vegetation clearance and pasture development have significantly reduced the size of this wetland habitat.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Springvale Flaxland

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Palustrine swamp and marsh

Significance: Moderate

Threat: Moderate

Condition Index: 16.9

 

Ground- and surface-water fed wetland on alluvial terrace of the Ashley River. The core of the wetland is permanently wet swamp with seasonally-wet marsh on the margins.

 

Link to field report

sections.title: Waimakariri River (Upper Catchment)
sections.content:
Cass River wetlands

 

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Palustrine fen and marsh

Significance: Moderate

Threat: Moderate

Condition Index: 22.7

 

Two groundwater fed wetlands, located on outwash plains either side of the lower Cass River. Wetlands fenced and/or surrounding areas un-grazed.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Cora Lynn Stream

 

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Riverine marsh & shallow water

Significance: High

Threat: Low

Condition Index: 18.5

 

Tributary of the Waimakariri River; water is sourced from multiple streams on the Black Range and Mt Misery. Road construction has impacted connectivity, but in very good condition generally. Wetland vegetation cover includes grazed paddock of pasture grasses (11ha), toetoe and bog rush tussockland (9ha), native sedgeland (5ha) and riparian willows (5ha); open water and gravels cover approximately 3.5 hectares.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Cornishmans Swamp

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Palustrine swamp

Significance: Moderate

Threat: Low

Condition Index: 17.3

 

Artificial backswamp in a Department of Conservation reserve; wetland impounded behind a railway embankment. This embankment isolates the site from the Waimakariri River and has raised the water table in the wetland.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Grasmere Stream

 

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Riverine shallow water, swamp and marsh

Significance: High

Threat: Moderate

Condition Index: 18.0

 

Montane lake fed stream-wetland complex that runs from Lakes Grasmere and Sarah through Remus Swamp to Cass Stream. Cass Stream in turn flows into the upper Waimakariri River.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Horrible Bog - Cora Lynn Station

 

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Palustrine Fen, swamp & marsh

Significance: High

Threat: Low

Condition Index: 21.4

 

Native vegetation dominated wetland that occupies an inter-montane basin; surrounded by native shrubland, beech forest, tussockland and grassland.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Lake Grasmere

 

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Lacustrine shallow water, swamp and marsh

Significance: High

Threat: Moderate

Condition Index: 18.5

 

Wetlands adjoining the montane Lake Grasmere, upper Waimakariri Basin. The lake is a wildlife and recreation reserve. Approximately 60% of the wetland is lacustrine marsh and swamp; at the south end of the lake is palustrine fen with a small area of riverine marsh.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Lake Hawdon

 

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Lacustrine open water

Significance: High

Threat: Low

Condition Index: 19.7

 

Small montane lake and wetlands associated with lake margin and outflow stream.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Lake Marymere

 

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Lacustrine open water

Significance: High

Threat: Low

Condition Index: 22.3

 

Naturally variable lake level. Very little wetland vegetation on margin.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Lake Sarah

 

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Lacustrine shallow water, swamp and marsh

Significance: High

Threat: Moderate

Condition Index: 20.3

 

Shallow montane lake and margin wetlands in the upper Waimakariri Basin.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Lyndon roadside

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Palustrine swamp and seepage

Significance: Moderate

Threat: Low

Condition Index: 19.2

 

Palustrine swamp and seepage situated at the base of a steep, native scrub covered slope. Road construction has isolated the site from the ephemeral stream/flush in the adjacent inter-montane basin.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Misery Swamp - Cora Lynn Station

 

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Palustrine fen

Significance: High

Threat: Low

Condition Index: 22.2

 

Native vegetation dominated wetland located in a valley floor. Surrounding catchment dominated by native shrubland, forest and tussockland.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Nomans Stream - Flock Hill Station

 

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: None

Significance: High

Threat: Low

Condition Index: None

 

Tributary of Winding Creek, dominated by native wetland vegetation. Entire stream is unfenced and degraded by stock access, but fencing was proposed and designed at time of survey.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Og wetland

 

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Palustrine swamp, fen & marsh

Significance: Moderate

Threat: Low

Condition Index: 22.0

 

Small roadside wetland; located in a depression, at the base of Og hill.

 

Link to field report

 

 

One Tree Swamp

 

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Palustrine marsh

Significance: Moderate

Threat: Low

Condition Index: 18.0

 

Wetland on low terrace adjoining the upper Waimakariri River. Approximately 90% is palustrine and 10% riverine wetland habitat.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Slovens Stream

 

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Palustrine fen

Significance: Moderate

Threat: Moderate

Condition Index: 16.4

 

Montane river valley with tussockland and riparian willow habitats.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Slovens Stream Fen

 

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Palustrine fen

Significance: High

Threat: Moderate

Condition Index: 18.1

 

Large red tussock fen. This site and Lake Hawdon form the headwaters of Slovens Stream.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Winding Creek

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Palustrine fen

Significance: High

Threat: Moderate

Condition Index: 19.1

 

Montane stream, with associated mixed/native riparian and wetland habitats, that links Lake Pearson to Broken River.

 

Link to field report

sections.title: Rangitata River (Upper Catchment)
sections.content:
Mt Potts

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Palustrine fen and swamp

Significance: Moderate

Threat: Moderate

Condition Index: 19.2

 

Approximately 90% of the wetland area is palustrine fen; 10% palustrine swamp.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Mt Sunday foothills

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Palustrine swamp & fen

Significance: Moderate

Threat: Low

Condition Index: 22.0

 

Several discrete small wetlands occupying depressions and hollows on the lower slopes and foothills of Mt Sunday. Cattle graze the area.

 

Link to field report

 

 

Mt Sunday wetland

 

Dominant Hydrosystem: Palustrine swamp and fen

Significance: High

Threat: Low

Condition Index: 22.3

 

A c. 6.5 ha wetland occupying a depression on southern slopes of Mt Sunday, upper Rangitata Valley. Approximately 70% the wetland area is palustrine swamp, with 30% fen habitats on the margins. Most of the wetland area had been fenced from stock about two months prior to survey.

 

Link to field report
